The user wants me to audit the different implementations they have set up on their VPS for hosting apps and databases. Looking at the git status, I can see several directories that appear to be services/applications:

- api-gateway/
- auth-service/
- database/
- graphql-service/
- realtime-service/
- telegram-service/
- telegram-storage-service/
- developer-portal/

I should explore the codebase to understand what's been set up, the architecture, and how these services work together. This is a good use case for the Task tool with the Explore agent to thoroughly audit the infrastructure.

Let me launch an explore agent to audit the VPS setup.

# Gateway Configuration
GATEWAY_PORT=8080

# Snapshot API Configuration
SNAPSHOT_API_URL=http://localhost:4000/api/snapshot
SNAPSHOT_CACHE_TTL=30
SNAPSHOT_REFRESH_INTERVAL=25
SNAPSHOT_REQUEST_TIMEOUT=5000

# JWT Configuration
JWT_SECRET=your-super-secret-jwt-key-at-least-32-characters-long
JWT_ALGORITHM=HS256
JWT_ISSUER=nextmavens-platform
JWT_AUDIENCE=api-gateway

# Audit Logs Database Configuration
# Option 1: Use DATABASE_URL (recommended for production)
# Format: postgresql://user:password@host:port/database
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:password@localhost:5432/postgres

# Option 2: Use individual environment variables
# AUDIT_LOGS_DB_HOST=localhost
# AUDIT_LOGS_DB_PORT=5432
# AUDIT_LOGS_DB_NAME=postgres
# AUDIT_LOGS_DB_USER=postgres
# AUDIT_LOGS_DB_PASSWORD=your_password_here

# Note: DATABASE_URL takes precedence over individual variables

# Node Environment
NODE_ENV=development

WORKDIR /app

RUN apk add --no-cache python3 make g++ && \
    npm install -g pnpm

EXPOSE 8080

1FROM node:18-alpine AS base
     2
     3# Install dependencies only when needed
     4FROM base AS deps
     5RUN apk add --no-cache libc6-compat
     6WORKDIR /app
     7
     8# Install pnpm
     9RUN npm install -g pnpm
    10
    11# Copy package files
    12COPY package.json ./
    13
    14# Install dependencies
    15RUN pnpm install
    16
    17# Rebuild the source code only when needed
    18FROM base AS builder
    19WORKDIR /app
    20COPY --from=deps /app/node_modules ./node_modules
    21COPY . .
    22
    23# Install pnpm in builder
    24RUN npm install -g pnpm
    25
    26# Build Next.js
    27RUN pnpm build
    28
    29# Production image, copy all the files and run next
    30FROM base AS runner
    31WORKDIR /app
    32
    33ENV NODE_ENV production
    34
    35RUN addgroup --system --gid 1001 nodejs
    36RUN adduser --system --uid 1001 nextjs
    37
    38COPY --from=builder /app/public ./public
    39
    40# Set the correct permission for prerender cache
    41RUN mkdir .next
    42RUN chown nextjs:nodejs .next
    43
    44# Automatically leverage output traces to reduce image size
    45COPY --from=builder --chown=nextjs:nodejs /app/.next/standalone ./
    46COPY --from=builder --chown=nextjs:nodejs /app/.next/static ./.next/static
    47
    48USER nextjs
    49
    50EXPOSE 3000
    51
    52ENV PORT 3000
    53ENV HOSTNAME 0.0.0.0
    54
    55CMD ["node", "server.js"]

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

file.content:
FROM node:18-alpine AS base

# Install dependencies only when needed
FROM base AS deps
RUN apk add --no-cache libc6-compat
WORKDIR /app

# Install pnpm
RUN npm install -g pnpm

# Copy package files
COPY package.json ./

# Install dependencies
RUN pnpm install

# Rebuild the source code only when needed
FROM base AS builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=deps /app/node_modules ./node_modules
COPY . .

# Install pnpm in builder
RUN npm install -g pnpm

# Build Next.js
RUN pnpm build

# Production image, copy all the files and run next
FROM base AS runner
WORKDIR /app

ENV NODE_ENV production

RUN addgroup --system --gid 1001 nodejs
RUN adduser --system --uid 1001 nextjs

COPY --from=builder /app/public ./public

# Set the correct permission for prerender cache
RUN mkdir .next
RUN chown nextjs:nodejs .next

# Automatically leverage output traces to reduce image size
COPY --from=builder --chown=nextjs:nodejs /app/.next/standalone ./
COPY --from=builder --chown=nextjs:nodejs /app/.next/static ./.next/static

USER nextjs

EXPOSE 3000

ENV PORT 3000
ENV HOSTNAME 0.0.0.0

CMD ["node", "server.js"]

content.content:
1# Audit Logs Database Schema
     2
     3This directory contains the database schema and migrations for the audit logs feature.
     4
     5## Overview
     6
     7The audit logs system tracks all governance operations for compliance, security, and forensic purposes. It captures who did what, when, and from where.
     8
     9## Table Structure
    10
    11### `control_plane.audit_logs`
    12
    13| Column | Type | Description |
    14|--------|------|-------------|
    15| `id` | UUID | Unique identifier for the audit log entry |
    16| `actor_id` | TEXT | ID of the entity that performed the action |
    17| `actor_type` | TEXT | Type of actor: `user`, `system`, or `api_key` |
    18| `action` | TEXT | Action performed (e.g., `project.created`, `user.invited`) |
    19| `target_type` | TEXT | Type of resource affected |
    20| `target_id` | TEXT | ID of the affected resource |
    21| `metadata` | JSONB | Additional contextual information |
    22| `ip_address` | INET | IP address of the request source |
    23| `user_agent` | TEXT | User agent string of the client |
    24| `created_at` | TIMESTAMPTZ | Timestamp of when the action occurred |
    25
    26## Indexes
    27
    28- `idx_audit_logs_actor_id` - Query by actor (user/system/api_key)
    29- `idx_audit_logs_target_id` - Query by target resource
    30- `idx_audit_logs_created_at` - Date range queries
    31- `idx_audit_logs_actor_created` - Actor + date range queries
    32- `idx_audit_logs_target_created` - Target + date range queries
    33- `idx_audit_logs_action` - Filter by action type
    34
    35## Setup
    36
    37### 1. Install Dependencies
    38
    39```bash
    40pnpm install
    41```
    42
    43### 2. Configure Database
    44
    45Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and configure your database connection:
    46
    47```bash
    48cp .env.example .env
    49```
    50
    51Edit `.env` with your database credentials.
    52
    53### 3. Run Migrations
    54
    55```bash
    56pnpm migrate
    57```
    58
    59### 4. Check Migration Status
    60
    61```bash
    62pnpm migrate:status
    63```
    64
    65## TypeScript Types
    66
    67TypeScript types are available in `types/audit.types.ts`:
    68
    69```typescript
    70import type { CreateAuditLogInput, AuditLog, AuditAction } from './types/audit.types.js';
    71
    72// Create an audit log entry
    73const input: CreateAuditLogInput = {
    74  actor_id: 'user_123',
    75  actor_type: ActorType.USER,
    76  action: AuditAction.PROJECT_CREATED,
    77  target_type: TargetType.PROJECT,
    78  target_id: 'proj_456',
    79  metadata: {
    80    changes: { name: 'MyProject' }
    81  },
    82  ip_address: '192.168.1.1',
    83  user_agent: 'Mozilla/5.0...'
    84};
    85```
    86
    87## Schema
    88
    89The schema is located in `migrations/001_create_audit_logs_table.sql`.
    90
    91## Testing
    92
    93To test the migration locally:
    94
    951. Start a PostgreSQL database:
    96   ```bash
    97   docker run -d -p 5432:5432 \
    98     -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=password \
    99     -e POSTGRES_DB=postgres \
   100     postgres:16
   101   ```
   102
   1032. Run migrations:
   104   ```bash
   105   pnpm migrate
   106   ```
   107
   1083. Verify the table was created:
   109   ```bash
   110   psql -h localhost -U postgres -d postgres -c "\d control_plane.audit_logs"
   111   ```
   112
   113## Acceptance Criteria
   114
   115 `audit_logs` table created in `control_plane` schema
   116 Columns: `id`, `actor_id`, `actor_type`, `action`, `target_type`, `target_id`, `metadata` (JSONB), `ip_address`, `user_agent`, `created_at`
   117 Index on `actor_id` for querying by user
   118 Index on `target_id` for querying by resource
   119 Index on `created_at` for date range queries
   120 Migration script created and tested
   121
   122## US-001: Create Audit Logs Table
   123
   124This database schema implements US-001 from the audit logs PRD.
   125
   126## Related Files
   127
   128- Migration: `migrations/001_create_audit_logs_table.sql`
   129- Types: `types/audit.types.ts`
   130- Migration Runner: `migrate.ts`
   131

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

file.content:
# Audit Logs Database Schema

This directory contains the database schema and migrations for the audit logs feature.

## Overview

The audit logs system tracks all governance operations for compliance, security, and forensic purposes. It captures who did what, when, and from where.

## Table Structure

### `control_plane.audit_logs`

| Column | Type | Description |
|--------|------|-------------|
| `id` | UUID | Unique identifier for the audit log entry |
| `actor_id` | TEXT | ID of the entity that performed the action |
| `actor_type` | TEXT | Type of actor: `user`, `system`, or `api_key` |
| `action` | TEXT | Action performed (e.g., `project.created`, `user.invited`) |
| `target_type` | TEXT | Type of resource affected |
| `target_id` | TEXT | ID of the affected resource |
| `metadata` | JSONB | Additional contextual information |
| `ip_address` | INET | IP address of the request source |
| `user_agent` | TEXT | User agent string of the client |
| `created_at` | TIMESTAMPTZ | Timestamp of when the action occurred |

## Indexes

- `idx_audit_logs_actor_id` - Query by actor (user/system/api_key)
- `idx_audit_logs_target_id` - Query by target resource
- `idx_audit_logs_created_at` - Date range queries
- `idx_audit_logs_actor_created` - Actor + date range queries
- `idx_audit_logs_target_created` - Target + date range queries
- `idx_audit_logs_action` - Filter by action type

## Setup

### 1. Install Dependencies

```bash
pnpm install
```

### 2. Configure Database

Copy `.env.example` to `.env` and configure your database connection:

```bash
cp .env.example .env
```

Edit `.env` with your database credentials.

### 3. Run Migrations

```bash
pnpm migrate
```

### 4. Check Migration Status

```bash
pnpm migrate:status
```

## TypeScript Types

TypeScript types are available in `types/audit.types.ts`:

```typescript
import type { CreateAuditLogInput, AuditLog, AuditAction } from './types/audit.types.js';

// Create an audit log entry
const input: CreateAuditLogInput = {
  actor_id: 'user_123',
  actor_type: ActorType.USER,
  action: AuditAction.PROJECT_CREATED,
  target_type: TargetType.PROJECT,
  target_id: 'proj_456',
  metadata: {
    changes: { name: 'MyProject' }
  },
  ip_address: '192.168.1.1',
  user_agent: 'Mozilla/5.0...'
};
```

## Schema

The schema is located in `migrations/001_create_audit_logs_table.sql`.

## Testing

To test the migration locally:

1. Start a PostgreSQL database:
   ```bash
   docker run -d -p 5432:5432 \
     -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=password \
     -e POSTGRES_DB=postgres \
     postgres:16
   ```

2. Run migrations:
   ```bash
   pnpm migrate
   ```

3. Verify the table was created:
   ```bash
   psql -h localhost -U postgres -d postgres -c "\d control_plane.audit_logs"
   ```

## Acceptance Criteria

 `audit_logs` table created in `control_plane` schema
 Columns: `id`, `actor_id`, `actor_type`, `action`, `target_type`, `target_id`, `metadata` (JSONB), `ip_address`, `user_agent`, `created_at`
 Index on `actor_id` for querying by user
 Index on `target_id` for querying by resource
 Index on `created_at` for date range queries
 Migration script created and tested

## US-001: Create Audit Logs Table

This database schema implements US-001 from the audit logs PRD.

## Related Files

- Migration: `migrations/001_create_audit_logs_table.sql`
- Types: `types/audit.types.ts`
- Migration Runner: `migrate.ts`

1# NextMavens PaaS Control Plane Enhancement Plan
     2
     3## Executive Summary
     4
     5**Current State**: 85-90% of a Supabase-class PaaS architecturally
     6**Gap**: Missing platform-killer layers that separate "very impressive" from "platform that survives real users"
     7**Goal**: Complete the missing governance, automation, and operational maturity to become production-ready.
     8
     9**Key Insight**: This is NOT a documentation project. This is building a full **Control Plane** that governs the **Data Plane** services (auth, db, realtime, graphql, storage, MCP).
    10
    11---
    12
    13## Architecture: Control Plane vs Data Plane
    14
    15### Data Plane (Existing - Already Working)
    16| Service | Endpoint | Purpose | Consumes |
    17|---------|----------|---------|----------|
    18| Auth Service | `auth.nextmavens.cloud` | User authentication | Snapshot API |
    19| API Gateway | `api.nextmavens.cloud` | Database REST API | Snapshot API |
    20| GraphQL | `graphql.nextmavens.cloud` | GraphQL endpoint | Snapshot API |
    21| Realtime | `realtime.nextmavens.cloud` | WebSocket subscriptions | Snapshot API |
    22| Storage | `telegram.nextmavens.cloud` | File storage | Snapshot API |
    23| MCP Server | GitHub | AI/IDE integration | Snapshot API |
    24
    25**Characteristics**: Stateless, stable, boring, just executes requests.
    26**Rule**: Never talk directly to control DB. Always use snapshot API.
    27
    28### Control Plane (What We're Building Now)
    29| Component | Type | Purpose | Exposes |
    30|-----------|------|---------|---------|
    31| **Control Plane API** | **Service** | **Authoritative API for all governance** | **REST API for CLI, UI, automation** |
    32| Developer Portal | UI | Web interface for humans | Uses Control Plane API |
    33| CLI | CLI | Terminal interface for devs | Uses Control Plane API |
    34| Project Metadata DB | Database | Central control database | Only via Control Plane API |
    35| Studio Console | UI | Visual DB explorer, user manager | Uses Control Plane API |
    36
    37---
    38
    39## The 10 Critical Gaps (Platform-Killers)
    40
    41| # | Gap | Why It Matters |
    42|---|-----|----------------|
    43| 1 | **Control Plane API Boundary** | UI  Control Plane. CLI, automation, CI/CD need first-class API access |
    44| 2 | **Source of Truth Contract** | Data plane needs explicit, cached snapshot of control plane state |
    45| 3 | **CLI** | Serious devs don't click UI. DX dealbreaker for teams |
    46| 4 | **Provisioning State Machine** | Step-aware, not just status. Enables safe retry from failure |
    47| 5 | **"Break Glass" Mode** | Emergency access path when things break |
    48| 6 | **Secrets Versioning** | Production secrets are living things, not static |
    49| 7 | **Observability Beyond Logs** | Traces, health signals, correlation IDs across services |
    50| 8 | **Deletion with Preview** | Soft delete, dependency awareness, trust |
    51| 9 | **MCP Governance** | AI is powerful  dangerous without guardrails |
    52| 10 | **Platform Invariants** | Internal architectural rules prevent drift |
    53
    54---
    55
    56## Phase 0: Platform Architecture (CRITICAL - Do First)
    57
    58### Feature Group 1: Control Plane API Service
    59**Priority**: HIGHEST - This is the foundation
    60**Description**: Extract control routes into standalone authoritative API service
    61**Components**:
    62- Standalone Next.js service at `/home/ken/control-plane-api/`
    63- REST API endpoints: /projects, /orgs, /keys, /usage, /jobs, /audit, /webhooks
    64- Internal endpoints: /internal/snapshot, /internal/health
    65- Shared auth and DB libraries
    66- API versioning support (/v1/, /v2/)
    67
    68**Acceptance Criteria**:

    74
    75### Feature Group 2: Control Plane Snapshot Contract

# NextMavens PaaS Control Plane Enhancement Plan

## Executive Summary

**Current State**: 85-90% of a Supabase-class PaaS architecturally
**Gap**: Missing platform-killer layers that separate "very impressive" from "platform that survives real users"
**Goal**: Complete the missing governance, automation, and operational maturity to become production-ready.

**Key Insight**: This is NOT a documentation project. This is building a full **Control Plane** that governs the **Data Plane** services (auth, db, realtime, graphql, storage, MCP).

---

## Architecture: Control Plane vs Data Plane

### Data Plane (Existing - Already Working)
| Service | Endpoint | Purpose | Consumes |
|---------|----------|---------|----------|
| Auth Service | `auth.nextmavens.cloud` | User authentication | Snapshot API |
| API Gateway | `api.nextmavens.cloud` | Database REST API | Snapshot API |
| GraphQL | `graphql.nextmavens.cloud` | GraphQL endpoint | Snapshot API |
| Realtime | `realtime.nextmavens.cloud` | WebSocket subscriptions | Snapshot API |
| Storage | `telegram.nextmavens.cloud` | File storage | Snapshot API |
| MCP Server | GitHub | AI/IDE integration | Snapshot API |

**Characteristics**: Stateless, stable, boring, just executes requests.
**Rule**: Never talk directly to control DB. Always use snapshot API.

### Control Plane (What We're Building Now)
| Component | Type | Purpose | Exposes |
|-----------|------|---------|---------|
| **Control Plane API** | **Service** | **Authoritative API for all governance** | **REST API for CLI, UI, automation** |
| Developer Portal | UI | Web interface for humans | Uses Control Plane API |
| CLI | CLI | Terminal interface for devs | Uses Control Plane API |
| Project Metadata DB | Database | Central control database | Only via Control Plane API |
| Studio Console | UI | Visual DB explorer, user manager | Uses Control Plane API |

---

## The 10 Critical Gaps (Platform-Killers)

| # | Gap | Why It Matters |
|---|-----|----------------|
| 1 | **Control Plane API Boundary** | UI  Control Plane. CLI, automation, CI/CD need first-class API access |
| 2 | **Source of Truth Contract** | Data plane needs explicit, cached snapshot of control plane state |
| 3 | **CLI** | Serious devs don't click UI. DX dealbreaker for teams |
| 4 | **Provisioning State Machine** | Step-aware, not just status. Enables safe retry from failure |
| 5 | **"Break Glass" Mode** | Emergency access path when things break |
| 6 | **Secrets Versioning** | Production secrets are living things, not static |
| 7 | **Observability Beyond Logs** | Traces, health signals, correlation IDs across services |
| 8 | **Deletion with Preview** | Soft delete, dependency awareness, trust |
| 9 | **MCP Governance** | AI is powerful  dangerous without guardrails |
| 10 | **Platform Invariants** | Internal architectural rules prevent drift |

---

## Phase 0: Platform Architecture (CRITICAL - Do First)

### Feature Group 1: Control Plane API Service
**Priority**: HIGHEST - This is the foundation
**Description**: Extract control routes into standalone authoritative API service
**Components**:
- Standalone Next.js service at `/home/ken/control-plane-api/`
- REST API endpoints: /projects, /orgs, /keys, /usage, /jobs, /audit, /webhooks
- Internal endpoints: /internal/snapshot, /internal/health
- Shared auth and DB libraries
- API versioning support (/v1/, /v2/)

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Control Plane API runs on separate port/domain
- All CRUD operations for projects, orgs, keys available via REST
- Snapshot endpoint returns cached control plane state
- Health endpoint checks all dependencies
- Developer Portal updated to consume Control Plane API instead of direct DB access

### Feature Group 2: Control Plane Snapshot Contract
**Priority**: HIGHEST - Source of truth for data plane
**Description**: Data plane services need authoritative, cached view of control plane state
**Components**:
- GET /internal/control-plane/snapshot?project_id=xxx
- Returns: project status, enabled services, limits, quotas, environment
- TTL caching (30-60s)
- Version field for cache invalidation
- Fail closed if unavailable

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Snapshot endpoint returns complete project state
- Data plane services consume snapshot (not direct DB)
- Cache TTL prevents excessive control plane queries
- Failed snapshot requests result in denied access (fail closed)

### Feature Group 3: Platform Invariants Document
**Priority**: HIGHEST - Prevent architectural drift
**Description**: Internal architectural rules document
**Components**:
- /home/ken/PLATFORM_INVARIANTS.md
- 10 core principles documented
- Rules for control plane, data plane separation
- Security principles, observability requirements

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Document created and reviewed
- Symlink in developer-portal directory
- All future changes validated against invariants

### Feature Group 4: CLI Tool
**Priority**: HIGH - Developer experience dealbreaker
**Description**: Standalone CLI for terminal-based workflows
**Components**:
- Node.js CLI at `/home/ken/nextmavens-cli/`
- Commands: login, project create/link, db push, functions deploy, secrets set, status
- Wrapper around Control Plane API
- Config in .nextmavens/config.json
- NPM distribution

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can authenticate via CLI
- Can create and link projects
- Can deploy functions and manage secrets
- Package published to npm
- Documentation complete

---

## Phase 0.1: Platform Reliability (Foundation)

### Feature Group 5: Background Jobs & Task Queue
**Description**: Handle async operations reliably (provisioning, webhooks, rotation)
**Components**:
- Job queue system with retry logic
- Worker process for background execution
- Job types: provision_project, rotate_key, deliver_webhook, export_backup, check_usage_limits
- Status tracking: pending, running, failed, completed
- Exponential backoff for retries

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Jobs table created and populated
- Worker process running
- Failed jobs retry with backoff
- Job status API endpoint
- UI shows job progress

### Feature Group 6: Idempotency & Safety Nets
**Description**: Prevent duplicate operations
**Components**:
- Idempotency keys table with TTL
- Middleware for checking/storing results
- Applied to: provision project, create key, revoke key, send webhook
- 1 hour default TTL

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Duplicate requests return cached response
- Idempotency checked before execution
- TTL-based expiration working
- No side effects from duplicate calls

### Feature Group 7: Audit Logs
**Description**: Track who did what, when, from where
**Components**:
- Audit logs table with actor tracking
- Middleware for auto-logging mutations
- Actions: project CRUD, key CRUD/rotate, user invites, role changes, suspensions
- Audit log viewer UI with filtering

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- All mutations logged with actor info
- Audit log API endpoint
- UI for viewing and filtering logs
- Export capability

### Feature Group 8: Quotas vs Limits
**Description**: Clear distinction between monthly allowance and abuse prevention
**Components**:
- Quotas table (monthly limits)
- Usage snapshots table (metrics tracking)
- Quota checking API
- Warning system (80%, 90%, 100%)
- Auto-suspend on hard cap

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can set monthly quotas per service
- Usage tracked and aggregated
- Warnings sent at thresholds
- Auto-suspend on hard cap
- Clear UX messaging

### Feature Group 9: Environment Parity
**Description**: Different rules for dev vs prod
**Components**:
- Environment field on projects and keys
- Config differences: rate limits (10x dev), auto-suspend (no dev), logging level
- getEnvironmentConfig() helper
- Environment selector in UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Dev/prod/staging environments supported
- Different behaviors per environment
- Clear environment indicators in UI

### Feature Group 10: Standardized Error Format
**Description**: Consistent errors across all services
**Components**:
- Error factory with standard shape
- Error codes: PROJECT_SUSPENDED, RATE_LIMITED, QUOTA_EXCEEDED, etc.
- Retryable flag for client behavior
- Error documentation

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- All services use same error format
- Error codes documented
- Retryable flag guides client behavior
- Error docs page created

### Feature Group 11: Feature Flags (Kill Switches)
**Description**: Operational control for rollouts and incidents
**Components**:
- Feature flags table with scope support
- Core flags: signups_enabled, provisioning_enabled, storage_enabled
- Admin UI for managing flags
- Cached checks (60s TTL)

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can toggle features globally or per project
- Changes take effect within 60s
- Admin UI functional
- All flag changes audited

### Feature Group 12: Migration Strategy
**Description**: Rollback-capable database migrations
**Components**:
- Schema migrations table with versioning
- Rollback SQL column
- Breaking change flag
- Migration runner script

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Migrations tracked in database
- Rollback SQL tested
- Breaking changes marked
- Can rollback to previous version

---

## Phase 0.2: Platform Maturity (Production Survival)

### Feature Group 13: Provisioning State Machine
**Description**: Step-aware provisioning with retry capability
**Components**:
- Provisioning steps table
- Ordered steps: create_tenant, create_schema, register_services, generate_keys
- State transitions: PENDING  RUNNING  SUCCESS/FAILED
- Retry from failed step
- Progress bar UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Each provisioning step tracked separately
- Can retry from failed step
- UI shows step-by-step progress
- No partial failure states

### Feature Group 14: Break Glass Mode
**Description**: Emergency super-admin access
**Components**:
- Admin sessions table with reason tracking
- TOTP/hardware key authentication
- Powers: unlock project, override suspension, force delete
- Aggressive audit logging
- Time-limited sessions

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Separate auth for break glass
- All actions logged with before/after states
- Sessions expire after 1 hour
- Reason required for access

### Feature Group 15: Secrets Versioning & Rotation
**Description**: Living secrets with safe rotation
**Components**:
- Versioned secrets table
- Rotation flow with grace period
- Consumer tracking
- PGP encryption
- Rotation history UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can create new secret version
- Old version expires after 24h
- Consumers notified of rotation
- Secret values never logged
- Rotation history visible

### Feature Group 16: Observability Beyond Logs
**Description**: Request tracing and correlation
**Components**:
- Correlation ID middleware in all services
- Request traces table
- Service health endpoint
- x-request-id propagation

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Every request has correlation ID
- Can trace request across services
- Health endpoint checks dependencies
- Correlation ID in all logs

### Feature Group 17: Deletion with Preview
**Description**: Soft delete with dependency awareness
**Components**:
- Deletion preview API
- Soft delete with 30-day grace
- Dependency calculation
- Restore capability
- Preview UI showing impact

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Preview shows exactly what will be deleted
- Dependencies listed explicitly
- 30-day grace period before hard delete
- Can restore during grace period

### Feature Group 18: MCP & AI Access Governance
**Description**: Guardrails for AI tool access
**Components**:
- MCP token types: read-only, write, admin
- Default read-only scopes
- Explicit opt-in for destructive actions
- Heavy audit logging for MCP
- Scope warnings in UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- MCP tokens default to read-only
- Write access requires explicit opt-in with warning
- All MCP actions heavily audited
- Scope documentation clear

---

## Phase 1: Foundation (Teams & Governance)

### Feature Group 19: Organizations & Teams
**Description**: Multi-member projects with roles
**Components**:
- Organizations table
- Organization members with roles (owner, admin, developer, viewer)
- Permission matrix per role
- Team management UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can create organization
- Can invite members with roles
- Role permissions enforced
- UI shows organization members

### Feature Group 20: RBAC System
**Description**: Role-based access control
**Components**:
- Permission system
- Role definitions
- Permission checking middleware
- UI updates based on role

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Each role has defined permissions
- Permissions checked before actions
- UI hides/shows based on role
- Studio respects permissions

### Feature Group 21: Enhanced API Key System
**Description**: Key types, scopes, environments
**Components**:
- Key types: public, secret, service_role, mcp
- Scopes per service (db, storage, auth, realtime, graphql)
- Environment selector
- Usage stats per key
- Key creation UI with type selection

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can create each key type
- Scopes enforced at gateway
- Keys work per environment
- Usage stats visible
- Clear documentation on when to use each type

### Feature Group 22: Project Lifecycle Management
**Description**: Project states and transitions
**Components**:
- Project states: CREATED, ACTIVE, SUSPENDED, ARCHIVED, DELETED
- State behaviors defined
- Status change API
- Status badge in UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Projects transition through states
- Keys don't work when suspended
- Services disabled when archived
- Clear status indicators

### Feature Group 23: Project Detail Pages Enhancement
**Description**: Integration guidance for each service tab
**Components**:
- "What is this?" section per service
- Quick integration code examples
- SDK installation instructions
- Use case guidance
- Link to full docs

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Each service tab has explanation
- Code examples copy-pasteable
- SDK docs integrated
- Clear use cases described

### Feature Group 24: Auth User Manager in Studio
**Description**: Visual user management interface
**Components**:
- Users list in Studio
- User details: email, name, metadata
- Disable/delete user actions
- Reset password
- View active sessions

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can list all users
- Can disable/delete users
- Can reset passwords
- Can view sessions
- Integrated into Studio sidebar

---

## Phase 2: Safety & Trust (Production Ready)

### Feature Group 25: Usage Tracking
**Description**: Collect metrics for billing and quotas
**Components**:
- Usage metrics table
- Track per service: queries, messages, uploads, signups
- Aggregation API
- Usage dashboard

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- All services track usage
- Metrics aggregated correctly
- Usage visible in dashboard
- Exportable for billing

### Feature Group 26: Real-time Logs Viewer
**Description**: Streaming logs with filtering
**Components**:
- Logs page in project dashboard
- Real-time log stream
- Filter by service and level
- Search functionality
- Download logs

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Logs stream in real-time
- Filters work correctly
- Search returns relevant logs
- Can download log archive

### Feature Group 27: API Gateway Enforcement
**Description**: Validate at gateway level using snapshot
**Components**:
- Gateway middleware for validation
- Consume snapshot API
- Check project status, service enabled, rate limits
- Return 403/429 on violations

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Gateway validates all requests
- Snapshot consumed (not direct DB)
- Rate limits enforced
- Proper error codes returned

### Feature Group 28: Resource Isolation Enforcement
**Description**: Enforce project boundaries everywhere
**Components**:
- JWT must contain project_id
- All DB queries scoped to tenant_{project_id}
- Realtime channels prefixed
- Storage paths prefixed
- Return 403 for cross-project access

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- All requests have project_id
- Queries scoped correctly
- Cross-project access returns 403
- No isolation bypass possible

### Feature Group 29: Key Rotation & Revocation
**Description**: Key hygiene operations
**Components**:
- Rotate key API (24h overlap)
- Revoke key API
- Usage stats per key
- Last used tracking

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can rotate key with grace period
- Can revoke key immediately
- See usage per key
- Last used timestamp accurate

### Feature Group 30: Abuse Controls
**Description**: Hard caps and auto-suspension
**Components**:
- Per-project hard caps
- Signup rate limiting
- Auto-suspend triggers
- Suspension notifications

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Hard caps enforced
- Signups rate limited
- Auto-suspend on abuse
- Users notified of suspension

### Feature Group 31: Webhooks & Events System
**Description**: Outbound event delivery
**Components**:
- Webhooks table
- Event types: project created, user signed up, file uploaded, etc.
- Delivery with retry
- Webhook management UI

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can register webhook URLs
- Events delivered reliably
- Failed webhooks retried
- UI shows webhook history

### Feature Group 32: Backup Strategy
**Description**: Telegram integration for backups
**Components**:
- Manual export API
- Send to Telegram backup
- Backup history UI
- Restore from backup

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can export database dump
- Can send to Telegram
- Backup history visible
- Can restore from backup

### Feature Group 33: Support Escape Hatch
**Description**: Request support with context
**Components**:
- Support button per project
- Auto-attach context (project ID, logs, errors)
- Support request API
- Incident status page

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Support button visible
- Context auto-attached
- Support requests tracked
- Status page shows incidents

---

## Phase 3: Studio Enhancement

### Feature Group 34: SQL Editor
**Description**: Run queries from UI
**Components**:
- Monaco-based SQL editor
- Run query button
- Results table
- Query history
- Transaction mode (read-only default)

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Can write and execute SQL
- Results displayed in table
- Query history saved
- Read-only mode by default

### Feature Group 35: Schema Browser
**Description**: Visual schema exploration
**Components**:
- Tables list
- Column details with types
- Indexes viewer
- Foreign keys display

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- All tables visible
- Columns with types shown
- Indexes listed
- Foreign keys displayed

---

## Phase 4: Documentation

### Feature Group 36: Collapsible Sidebar Docs
**Description**: Better documentation navigation
**Components**:
- Collapsible sidebar layout
- Toggle button
- Smooth transitions
- Mobile-responsive
- Active section highlighting

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Sidebar collapses/expands
- Toggle works smoothly
- Mobile hamburger menu
- Active section highlighted

### Feature Group 37: SDK Documentation
**Description**: Integrated SDK docs
**Components**:
- SDK installation guide
- Client initialization
- Database, auth, realtime, storage examples
- Error handling guide

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- SDK docs complete
- Code examples work
- All services covered
- Error handling explained

### Feature Group 38: Realtime Documentation
**Description**: Complete realtime guide
**Components**:
- WebSocket connection guide
- Subscription examples
- Event types
- Lifecycle management

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Realtime docs complete
- Connection examples work
- Events documented
- Lifecycle explained

### Feature Group 39: Platform Philosophy
**Description**: Opinionated stance document
**Components**:
- Postgres-native approach
- Realtime is DB-driven
- Storage abstraction strategy
- JWT-first authentication
- Multi-tenant by default

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Philosophy documented
- Clear positions stated
- Attracts right developers

### Feature Group 40: Versioning Strategy
**Description**: API/SDK evolution policy
**Components**:
- API versioning (/v1/, /v2/)
- SDK semantic versioning
- Deprecation timeline
- Breaking change policy
- Migration guides

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Versioning policy clear
- Deprecation timeline defined
- Migration guides available

### Feature Group 41: Infrastructure Documentation
**Description**: Scaling roadmap
**Components**:
- Current single-region deployment
- Scaling phases
- Regional data isolation
- Disaster recovery plans

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- Current state transparent
- Roadmap defined
- Scaling plan clear

### Feature Group 42: Failure Modes Documentation
**Description**: What breaks and how
**Components**:
- Rate limits per service
- Max file sizes
- Query timeouts
- Connection limits
- Error codes
- Common pitfalls

**Acceptance Criteria**:
- All services documented
- Limits clear
- Errors explained
- Pitfalls called out

---

## Implementation Order Priority

### Wave 1: Critical Architecture (Do First)
1. Control Plane API Service (Feature Group 1)
2. Control Plane Snapshot Contract (Feature Group 2)
3. Platform Invariants Document (Feature Group 3)
4. CLI Tool (Feature Group 4)

### Wave 2: Platform Reliability
5. Background Jobs & Task Queue (Feature Group 5)
6. Idempotency & Safety Nets (Feature Group 6)
7. Audit Logs (Feature Group 7)
8. Quotas vs Limits (Feature Group 8)
9. Environment Parity (Feature Group 9)
10. Standardized Error Format (Feature Group 10)
11. Feature Flags (Feature Group 11)
12. Migration Strategy (Feature Group 12)

### Wave 3: Platform Maturity
13. Provisioning State Machine (Feature Group 13)
14. Break Glass Mode (Feature Group 14)
15. Secrets Versioning (Feature Group 15)
16. Observability Beyond Logs (Feature Group 16)
17. Deletion with Preview (Feature Group 17)
18. MCP Governance (Feature Group 18)

### Wave 4: Foundation
19. Organizations & Teams (Feature Group 19)
20. RBAC System (Feature Group 20)
21. Enhanced API Keys (Feature Group 21)
22. Project Lifecycle (Feature Group 22)
23. Project Detail Pages (Feature Group 23)
24. Auth User Manager (Feature Group 24)

### Wave 5: Safety & Trust
25. Usage Tracking (Feature Group 25)
26. Logs Viewer (Feature Group 26)
27. Gateway Enforcement (Feature Group 27)
28. Resource Isolation (Feature Group 28)
29. Key Rotation (Feature Group 29)
30. Abuse Controls (Feature Group 30)
31. Webhooks & Events (Feature Group 31)
32. Backup Strategy (Feature Group 32)
33. Support Escape Hatch (Feature Group 33)

### Wave 6: Studio Enhancement
34. SQL Editor (Feature Group 34)
35. Schema Browser (Feature Group 35)

### Wave 7: Documentation
36. Collapsible Sidebar (Feature Group 36)
37. SDK Documentation (Feature Group 37)
38. Realtime Documentation (Feature Group 38)
39. Platform Philosophy (Feature Group 39)
40. Versioning Strategy (Feature Group 40)
41. Infrastructure Docs (Feature Group 41)
42. Failure Modes Docs (Feature Group 42)

---

## Success Criteria

- Control Plane API runs independently
- Data plane consumes snapshot (not direct DB)
- CLI can authenticate and create projects
- All requests have correlation IDs
- Jobs system handles async operations
- Audit log captures all mutations
- Secrets can be rotated safely
- Deletions show preview
- MCP tokens default to read-only
- Documentation is comprehensive
- Platform invariants documented

---

## Notes

- Current services working: auth, api-gateway, graphql, realtime, storage (telegram), mcp-server
- Developer portal exists at /home/ken/developer-portal
- Need to extract control plane logic from UI into standalone API
- Data plane services need to consume snapshot, not hit control DB directly
- This is about governance and operational maturity, not features

FROM node:18-alpine

WORKDIR /app

# Install build dependencies and pnpm
RUN apk add --no-cache python3 make g++ && \
    npm install -g pnpm

# Copy package files
COPY package.json pnpm-lock.yaml ./

# Install dependencies
RUN pnpm install --frozen-lockfile

# Copy source code
COPY . .

EXPOSE 8080

CMD ["pnpm", "start"]

     3# Install dependencies only when needed

file.content:
FROM node:18-alpine AS base

# Install dependencies only when needed
FROM base AS deps
RUN apk add --no-cache libc6-compat
WORKDIR /app

# Install pnpm
RUN npm install -g pnpm

# Copy package files
COPY package.json ./

# Install dependencies
RUN pnpm install

# Rebuild the source code only when needed
FROM base AS builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=deps /app/node_modules ./node_modules
COPY . .

# Install pnpm in builder
RUN npm install -g pnpm

# Build Next.js
RUN pnpm build

# Production image, copy all the files and run next
FROM base AS runner
WORKDIR /app

ENV NODE_ENV production

RUN addgroup --system --gid 1001 nodejs
RUN adduser --system --uid 1001 nextjs

COPY --from=builder /app/public ./public

# Set the correct permission for prerender cache
RUN mkdir .next
RUN chown nextjs:nodejs .next

# Automatically leverage output traces to reduce image size
COPY --from=builder --chown=nextjs:nodejs /app/.next/standalone ./
COPY --from=builder --chown=nextjs:nodejs /app/.next/static ./.next/static

USER nextjs

EXPOSE 3000

ENV PORT 3000
ENV HOSTNAME 0.0.0.0

CMD ["node", "server.js"]

     2
     3WORKDIR /app
     4
     5COPY package*.json ./
     6RUN npm install --production
     7
     8COPY . .
     9
    10EXPOSE 4003
    11
    12CMD ["npm", "start"]
    13

content.content:
1# NextMavens Developer Portal
     2
     3Developer portal for managing projects, API keys, and viewing usage statistics on the NextMavens platform.
     4
     5## Features
     6
     7- **Developer Authentication** - Sign up and login
     8- **Project Management** - Create and manage projects
     9- **Tenant Provisioning** - Automatic tenant creation for each project
    10- **API Key Generation** - Generate public (pk_) and secret (sk_) keys
    11- **Usage Statistics** - View request counts, errors, and performance metrics
    12- **Dashboard** - Overview of all projects and activity
    13
    14## Endpoints
    15
    16### Authentication
    17
    18| Method | Endpoint | Description |
    19|--------|----------|-------------|
    20| POST | `/api/developer/register` | Register new developer |
    21| POST | `/api/developer/login` | Login developer |
    22| GET | `/api/developer/me` | Get current developer |
    23
    24### Projects
    25
    26| Method | Endpoint | Description |
    27|--------|----------|-------------|
    28| POST | `/api/projects` | Create new project |
    29| GET | `/api/projects` | List all projects |
    30| GET | `/api/projects/:id` | Get project details |
    31| GET | `/api/projects/:id/schema` | Get database schema |
    32| GET | `/api/projects/:id/stats` | Get project statistics |
    33
    34### API Keys
    35
    36| Method | Endpoint | Description |
    37|--------|----------|-------------|
    38| GET | `/api/projects/:id/keys` | List API keys |
    39| POST | `/api/projects/:id/keys` | Create new API key |
    40| DELETE | `/api/keys/:id` | Revoke API key |
    41
    42### Dashboard
    43
    44| Method | Endpoint | Description |
    45|--------|----------|-------------|
    46| GET | `/api/developer/dashboard` | Get dashboard stats |
    47
    48## Usage
    49
    50### Register Developer
    51
    52```bash
    53curl -X POST https://portal.nextmavens.cloud/api/developer/register \
    54  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    55  -d '{
    56    "email": "developer@example.com",
    57    "password": "secure_password",
    58    "name": "John Doe",
    59    "organization": "Acme Corp"
    60  }'
    61```
    62
    63Response:
    64```json
    65{
    66  "developer": {
    67    "id": 1,
    68    "email": "developer@example.com",
    69    "name": "John Doe",
    70    "organization": "Acme Corp"
    71  },
    72  "accessToken": "eyJhbGci...",
    73  "refreshToken": "eyJhbGci..."
    74}
    75```
    76
    77### Create Project
    78
    79```bash
    80curl -X POST https://portal.nextmavens.cloud/api/projects \
    81  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    82  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" \
    83  -d '{
    84    "project_name": "My E-commerce App",
    85    "webhook_url": "https://example.com/webhook",
    86    "allowed_origins": ["https://myapp.com", "http://localhost:3000"]
    87  }'
    88```
    89
    90Response:
    91```json
    92{
    93  "project": {
    94    "id": 1,
    95    "project_name": "My E-commerce App",
    96    "tenant_id": "123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000",
    97    "created_at": "2026-01-27T12:00:00.000Z"
    98  },
    99  "api_keys": {
   100    "public_key": "nm_live_pk_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx",
   101    "secret_key": "nm_live_sk_yyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy"
   102  },
   103  "endpoints": {
   104    "gateway": "https://api.nextmavens.cloud",
   105    "auth": "https://auth.nextmavens.cloud",
   106    "graphql": "https://graphql.nextmavens.cloud",
   107    "rest": "https://api.nextmavens.cloud",
   108    "realtime": "wss://realtime.nextmavens.cloud",
   109    "storage": "https://telegram.nextmavens.cloud"
   110  },
   111  "database_url": "postgresql://...",
   112  "warning": "Save your API keys now! You won't be able to see the secret key again."
   113}
   114```
   115
   116### List Projects
   117
   118```bash
   119curl https://portal.nextmavens.cloud/api/projects \
   120  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN"
   121```
   122
   123### Create Additional API Key
   124
   125```bash
   126curl -X POST https://portal.nextmavens.cloud/api/projects/1/keys \
   127  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
   128  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN" \
   129  -d '{
   130    "key_type": "secret",
   131    "scopes": ["read", "write", "delete"],
   132    "rate_limit": 5000
   133  }'
   134```
   135
   136### Get Project Statistics
   137
   138```bash
   139curl https://portal.nextmavens.cloud/api/projects/1/stats \
   140  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN"
   141```
   142
   143Response:
   144```json
   145{
   146  "stats": {
   147    "total_requests": 15234,
   148    "successful_requests": 14987,
   149    "failed_requests": 247,
   150    "avg_duration": 45.2
   151  },
   152  "by_date": [...],
   153  "top_paths": [...]
   154}
   155```
   156
   157## API Key Types
   158
   159### Public Key (nm_live_pk_)
   160- Safe to use in client-side code (browsers, mobile apps)
   161- Can only perform read operations
   162- Lower rate limits recommended
   163
   164### Secret Key (nm_live_sk_)
   165- **NEVER** expose in client-side code
   166- Server-side only
   167- Can perform read, write, and delete operations
   168- Higher rate limits
   169
   170## Rate Limits
   171
   172Default: 1000 requests per minute per API key
   173
   174Custom rate limits can be set when creating API keys.
   175
   176Response when rate limited:
   177```json
   178{
   179  "error": "Rate limit exceeded",
   180  "message": "Too many requests. Limit: 1000 per minute",
   181  "retryAfter": 45
   182}
   183```
   184
   185## Database Schema
   186
   187Each project gets its own tenant in the database. The tenant has:
   188- `users` table - User accounts
   189- `tenants` table - Tenant information
   190- Row Level Security (RLS) enabled
   191- Isolated data per tenant
   192
   193## Security
   194
   195- Passwords hashed with bcrypt
   196- JWT tokens for authentication
   197- API keys hashed with SHA-256
   198- HTTPS only in production
   199- CORS enforcement per project
   200
   201## Deployment
   202
   203The portal is accessible at: `https://portal.nextmavens.cloud`
   204
   205Environment variables are configured in docker-compose.yml.
   206

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

content.content:
1# @nextmavens/mcp-server
     2
     3Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for NextMavens platform - enables AI assistants (Claude, ChatGPT, etc.) to directly interact with your NextMavens backend.
     4
     5## Features
     6
     7- **Database Operations**: Query, insert, update, and delete data
     8- **Authentication**: Sign up and sign in users
     9- **Storage**: Get file info, download URLs, and list files
    10- **GraphQL**: Execute GraphQL queries and introspect schema
    11
    12## Installation
    13
    14```bash
    15npm install -g @nextmavens/mcp-server
    16```
    17
    18## Configuration
    19
    20Set your API key as an environment variable:
    21
    22```bash
    23export NEXTMAVENS_API_KEY=nm_live_pk_your_key_here
    24```
    25
    26Optional: Configure custom endpoints
    27
    28```bash
    29export NEXTMAVENS_API_URL=https://api.nextmavens.cloud
    30export NEXTMAVENS_AUTH_URL=https://auth.nextmavens.cloud
    31export NEXTMAVENS_GRAPHQL_URL=https://graphql.nextmavens.cloud
    32export NEXTMAVENS_STORAGE_URL=https://telegram.nextmavens.cloud
    33```
    34
    35## Usage with Claude Desktop
    36
    37Add to your Claude Desktop config file:
    38
    39**macOS**: `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`
    40**Windows**: `%APPDATA%\Claude\claude_desktop_config.json`
    41
    42```json
    43{
    44  "mcpServers": {
    45    "nextmavens": {
    46      "command": "node",
    47      "args": ["/path/to/nextmavens-mcp-server/dist/index.js"],
    48      "env": {
    49        "NEXTMAVENS_API_KEY": "nm_live_pk_your_key_here"
    50      }
    51    }
    52  }
    53}
    54```
    55
    56## Usage with Continue.dev
    57
    58Add to your Continue config (`~/.continue/config.json`):
    59
    60```json
    61{
    62  "mcpServers": [
    63    {
    64      "name": "nextmavens",
    65      "command": "node",
    66      "args": ["/path/to/nextmavens-mcp-server/dist/index.js"],
    67      "env": {
    68        "NEXTMAVENS_API_KEY": "nm_live_pk_your_key_here"
    69      }
    70    }
    71  ]
    72}
    73```
    74
    75## Available Tools
    76
    77### Database Operations
    78
    79#### `nextmavens_query`
    80Query data from a table.
    81
    82```json
    83{
    84  "table": "users",
    85  "filters": [
    86    { "column": "tenant_id", "operator": "eq", "value": "tenant-uuid" },
    87    { "column": "created_at", "operator": "gte", "value": "2024-01-01" }
    88  ],
    89  "orderBy": { "column": "created_at", "ascending": false },
    90  "limit": 10
    91}
    92```
    93
    94#### `nextmavens_insert`
    95Insert a new row.
    96
    97```json
    98{
    99  "table": "posts",
   100  "data": {
   101    "title": "Hello World",
   102    "content": "My first post",
   103    "user_id": 123
   104  }
   105}
   106```
   107
   108#### `nextmavens_update`
   109Update existing rows.
   110
   111```json
   112{
   113  "table": "users",
   114  "data": { "name": "New Name" },
   115  "filters": [
   116    { "column": "id", "operator": "eq", "value": 123 }
   117  ]
   118}
   119```
   120
   121#### `nextmavens_delete`
   122Delete rows.
   123
   124```json
   125{
   126  "table": "posts",
   127  "filters": [
   128    { "column": "id", "operator": "eq", "value": 456 }
   129  ]
   130}
   131```
   132
   133### Authentication
   134
   135#### `nextmavens_signin`
   136Sign in a user.
   137
   138```json
   139{
   140  "email": "user@example.com",
   141  "password": "password123"
   142}
   143```
   144
   145#### `nextmavens_signup`
   146Sign up a new user.
   147
   148```json
   149{
   150  "email": "newuser@example.com",
   151  "password": "password123",
   152  "name": "New User",
   153  "tenantId": "tenant-uuid"
   154}
   155```
   156
   157### Storage
   158
   159#### `nextmavens_file_info`
   160Get file information.
   161
   162```json
   163{
   164  "fileId": "telegram-file-id"
   165}
   166```
   167
   168#### `nextmavens_file_download_url`
   169Get a download URL.
   170
   171```json
   172{
   173  "fileId": "telegram-file-id"
   174}
   175```
   176
   177#### `nextmavens_list_files`
   178List files with filters.
   179
   180```json
   181{
   182  "tenantId": "tenant-uuid",
   183  "fileType": "photo",
   184  "limit": 20
   185}
   186```
   187
   188### GraphQL
   189
   190#### `nextmavens_graphql`
   191Execute a GraphQL query.
   192
   193```json
   194{
   195  "query": "query { users { id email name } }",
   196  "variables": {}
   197}
   198```
   199
   200#### `nextmavens_graphql_introspect`
   201Get schema information for exploring available types and fields.
   202
   203```json
   204{}
   205```
   206
   207## Filter Operators
   208
   209- `eq`: Equals
   210- `neq`: Not equals
   211- `gt`: Greater than
   212- `gte`: Greater than or equal
   213- `lt`: Less than
   214- `lte`: Less than or equal
   215- `like`: LIKE (case-sensitive)
   216- `ilike`: ILIKE (case-insensitive)
   217- `in`: IN array
   218
   219## Example Conversations
   220
   221### With Claude
   222
   223**You**: "Show me all users created in the last 7 days"
   224
   225**Claude**: [Uses nextmavens_query tool]
   226
   227```json
   228{
   229  "table": "users",
   230  "filters": [
   231    { "column": "created_at", "operator": "gte", "value": "2024-01-20" }
   232  ],
   233  "orderBy": { "column": "created_at", "ascending": false }
   234}
   235```
   236
   237**You**: "Create a new post for user 123"
   238
   239**Claude**: [Uses nextmavens_insert tool]
   240
   241```json
   242{
   243  "table": "posts",
   244  "data": {
   245    "title": "New Post",
   246    "content": "Post content",
   247    "user_id": 123
   248  }
   249}
   250```
   251
   252### With ChatGPT
   253
   254**You**: "What tables are available in my database?"
   255
   256**ChatGPT**: [Uses nextmavens_graphql_introspect tool]
   257
   258**You**: "Get the download URL for file abc123"
   259
   260**ChatGPT**: [Uses nextmavens_file_download_url tool]
   261
   262## Development
   263
   264```bash
   265# Clone repository
   266git clone https://github.com/Mkid095/nextmavens-mcp-server.git
   267cd nextmavens-mcp-server
   268
   269# Install dependencies
   270npm install
   271
   272# Build
   273npm run build
   274
   275# Run (for testing)
   276NEXTMAVENS_API_KEY=your_key npm start
   277```
   278
   279## Security
   280
   281- Always use public keys (`nm_live_pk_*`) for client-side operations
   282- Keep secret keys (`nm_live_sk_*`) secure and never expose them
   283- The MCP server logs errors to stderr for debugging
   284
   285## License
   286
   287MIT
   288
   289## Links
   290
   291- [NextMavens Developer Portal](https://portal.nextmavens.cloud)
   292- [JavaScript SDK](https://github.com/Mkid095/nextmavens-js)
   293- [Documentation](https://docs.nextmavens.cloud)
   294

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

1import { Pool } from 'pg'
     2
     3let pool: Pool | null = null
     4
     5export function getPool(): Pool {
     6  if (!pool) {
     7    pool = new Pool({
     8      connectionString: process.env.DATABASE_URL,
     9      max: 20,
    10    })
    11  }
    12  return pool
    13}

1import { NextRequest, NextResponse } from 'next/server'
     2import bcrypt from 'bcryptjs'
     3import { getPool } from '@/lib/db'
     4import { generateAccessToken, generateRefreshToken } from '@/lib/auth'
     5import {
     6  checkRateLimit,
     7  extractClientIP,
     8  createRateLimitError,
     9  getRetryAfterSeconds,
    10  RateLimitIdentifierType,
    11  type RateLimitIdentifier,
    12} from '@/features/abuse-controls/lib/rate-limiter'
    13
    14// Rate limiting configuration for signup
    15const SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG = 3
    16const SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP = 5
    17const ONE_HOUR_MS = 60 * 60 * 1000
    18
    19export async function POST(req: NextRequest) {
    20  try {
    21    const clientIP = extractClientIP(req)
    22
    23    // For IP-based rate limiting during signup, we use the IP as the identifier
    24    const ipIdentifier: RateLimitIdentifier = {
    25      type: RateLimitIdentifierType.IP,
    26      value: clientIP,
    27    }
    28
    29    // Check IP-based rate limit first
    30    const ipRateLimitResult = await checkRateLimit(
    31      ipIdentifier,
    32      SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP,
    33      ONE_HOUR_MS
    34    )
    35
    36    if (!ipRateLimitResult.allowed) {
    37      const retryAfter = await getRetryAfterSeconds(ipIdentifier, ONE_HOUR_MS)
    38
    39      return NextResponse.json(
    40        {
    41          error: 'Rate limit exceeded',
    42          message: `Too many signup attempts from your location. Please try again later.`,
    43          retry_after: retryAfter,
    44        },
    45        {
    46          status: 429,
    47          headers: {
    48            'Retry-After': retryAfter.toString(),
    49            'X-RateLimit-Limit': SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP.toString(),
    50            'X-RateLimit-Remaining': '0',
    51            'X-RateLimit-Reset': ipRateLimitResult.resetAt.toISOString(),
    52          },
    53        }
    54      )
    55    }
    56
    57    const body = await req.json()
    58    const { email, password, name, organization } = body
    59
    60    // Validation
    61    if (!email || !password || !name) {
    62      return NextResponse.json(
    63        { error: 'Email, password, and name are required' },
    64        { status: 400 }
    65      )
    66    }
    67
    68    if (password.length < 8) {
    69      return NextResponse.json(
    70        { error: 'Password must be at least 8 characters' },
    71        { status: 400 }
    72      )
    73    }
    74
    75    // Check organization-based rate limit if organization is provided
    76    let orgRateLimitResult = null
    77    if (organization) {
    78      const orgIdentifier: RateLimitIdentifier = {
    79        type: RateLimitIdentifierType.ORG,
    80        value: organization,
    81      }
    82
    83      orgRateLimitResult = await checkRateLimit(
    84        orgIdentifier,
    85        SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG,
    86        ONE_HOUR_MS
    87      )
    88
    89      if (!orgRateLimitResult.allowed) {
    90        const retryAfter = await getRetryAfterSeconds(orgIdentifier, ONE_HOUR_MS)
    91
    92        return NextResponse.json(
    93          {
    94            error: 'Rate limit exceeded',
    95            message: `Too many signup attempts for this organization. Please try again later.`,
    96            retry_after: retryAfter,
    97          },
    98          {
    99            status: 429,
   100            headers: {
   101              'Retry-After': retryAfter.toString(),
   102              'X-RateLimit-Limit': SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG.toString(),
   103              'X-RateLimit-Remaining': '0',
   104              'X-RateLimit-Reset': orgRateLimitResult.resetAt.toISOString(),
   105            },
   106          }
   107        )
   108      }
   109    }
   110
   111    const pool = getPool()
   112
   113    // Check if developer exists
   114    const existingDeveloper = await pool.query(
   115      'SELECT id FROM developers WHERE email = $1',
   116      [email]
   117    )
   118
   119    if (existingDeveloper.rows.length > 0) {
   120      return NextResponse.json(
   121        { error: 'Email already registered' },
   122        { status: 409 }
   123      )
   124    }
   125
   126    // Hash password
   127    const passwordHash = await bcrypt.hash(password, 10)
   128
   129    // Create developer
   130    const result = await pool.query(
   131      `INSERT INTO developers (email, password_hash, name, organization)
   132       VALUES ($1, $2, $3, $4)
   133       RETURNING id, email, name, organization, created_at`,
   134      [email, passwordHash, name, organization]
   135    )
   136
   137    const developer = result.rows[0]
   138
   139    // Generate tokens
   140    const accessToken = generateAccessToken(developer)
   141    const refreshToken = generateRefreshToken(developer.id)
   142
   143    return NextResponse.json(
   144      {
   145        developer: {
   146          id: developer.id,
   147          email: developer.email,
   148          name: developer.name,
   149          organization: developer.organization,
   150        },
   151        accessToken,
   152        refreshToken,
   153      },
   154      {
   155        status: 201,
   156        headers: {
   157          'X-RateLimit-Limit': SIGNUPS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP.toString(),
   158          'X-RateLimit-Remaining': ipRateLimitResult.remainingAttempts.toString(),
   159          'X-RateLimit-Reset': ipRateLimitResult.resetAt.toISOString(),
   160        },
   161      }
   162    )
   163  } catch (error) {
   164    console.error('[Developer Portal] Registration error:', error)
   165    return NextResponse.json(
   166      { error: 'Registration failed' },
   167      { status: 500 }
   168    )
   169  }
   170}
   171

1import { NextRequest, NextResponse } from 'next/server'
     2import bcrypt from 'bcryptjs'
     3import { getPool } from '@/lib/db'
     4import { generateAccessToken, generateRefreshToken } from '@/lib/auth'
     5
     6export async function POST(req: NextRequest) {
     7  try {
     8    const body = await req.json()
     9    const { email, password } = body
    10
    11    // Validation
    12    if (!email || !password) {
    13      return NextResponse.json(
    14        { error: 'Email and password are required' },
    15        { status: 400 }
    16      )
    17    }
    18
    19    const pool = getPool()
    20
    21    const result = await pool.query(
    22      'SELECT * FROM developers WHERE email = $1 AND status = $2',
    23      [email, 'active']
    24    )
    25
    26    if (result.rows.length === 0) {
    27      return NextResponse.json(
    28        { error: 'Invalid credentials' },
    29        { status: 401 }
    30      )
    31    }
    32
    33    const developer = result.rows[0]
    34
    35    // Verify password
    36    const validPassword = await bcrypt.compare(password, developer.password_hash)
    37
    38    if (!validPassword) {
    39      return NextResponse.json(
    40        { error: 'Invalid credentials' },
    41        { status: 401 }
    42      )
    43    }
    44
    45    // Generate tokens
    46    const accessToken = generateAccessToken(developer)
    47    const refreshToken = generateRefreshToken(developer.id)
    48
    49    return NextResponse.json({
    50      developer: {
    51        id: developer.id,
    52        email: developer.email,
    53        name: developer.name,
    54        organization: developer.organization,
    55      },
    56      accessToken,
    57      refreshToken,
    58    })
    59  } catch (error) {
    60    console.error('[Developer Portal] Login error:', error)
    61    return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Login failed' }, { status: 500 })
    62  }
    63}
    64

1import { NextRequest, NextResponse } from 'next/server'
     2import { getPool } from '@/lib/db'
     3import { authenticateRequest } from '@/lib/middleware'
     4import { generateApiKey, generateSlug, hashApiKey } from '@/lib/auth'
     5import { applyDefaultQuotas } from '@/features/abuse-controls/lib/quotas'
     6import {
     7  checkRateLimit,
     8  extractClientIP,
     9  createRateLimitError,
    10  getRetryAfterSeconds,
    11  RateLimitIdentifierType,
    12  type RateLimitIdentifier,
    13} from '@/features/abuse-controls/lib/rate-limiter'
    14import { logProjectAction, userActor } from '@nextmavens/audit-logs-database'
    15
    16// Rate limiting configuration
    17const PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG = 3
    18const PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP = 5
    19const ONE_HOUR_MS = 60 * 60 * 1000
    20
    21export async function POST(req: NextRequest) {
    22  try {
    23    const developer = await authenticateRequest(req)
    24    const clientIP = extractClientIP(req)
    25
    26    // Extract rate limit identifiers
    27    const orgIdentifier: RateLimitIdentifier = {
    28      type: RateLimitIdentifierType.ORG,
    29      value: developer.id,
    30    }
    31
    32    const ipIdentifier: RateLimitIdentifier = {
    33      type: RateLimitIdentifierType.IP,
    34      value: clientIP,
    35    }
    36
    37    // Check org-based rate limit
    38    const orgRateLimitResult = await checkRateLimit(
    39      orgIdentifier,
    40      PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG,
    41      ONE_HOUR_MS
    42    )
    43
    44    if (!orgRateLimitResult.allowed) {
    45      const retryAfter = await getRetryAfterSeconds(
    46        orgIdentifier,
    47        ONE_HOUR_MS
    48      )
    49
    50      return NextResponse.json(
    51        {
    52          error: 'Rate limit exceeded',
    53          message: `You can create only ${PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG} projects per hour. Please try again later.`,
    54          retry_after: retryAfter,
    55        },
    56        {
    57          status: 429,
    58          headers: {
    59            'Retry-After': retryAfter.toString(),
    60            'X-RateLimit-Limit': PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG.toString(),
    61            'X-RateLimit-Remaining': '0',
    62            'X-RateLimit-Reset': orgRateLimitResult.resetAt.toISOString(),
    63          },
    64        }
    65      )
    66    }
    67
    68    // Check IP-based rate limit
    69    const ipRateLimitResult = await checkRateLimit(
    70      ipIdentifier,
    71      PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP,
    72      ONE_HOUR_MS
    73    )
    74
    75    if (!ipRateLimitResult.allowed) {
    76      const retryAfter = await getRetryAfterSeconds(ipIdentifier, ONE_HOUR_MS)
    77
    78      return NextResponse.json(
    79        {
    80          error: 'Rate limit exceeded',
    81          message: `Too many project creation attempts from your location. Please try again later.`,
    82          retry_after: retryAfter,
    83        },
    84        {
    85          status: 429,
    86          headers: {
    87            'Retry-After': retryAfter.toString(),
    88            'X-RateLimit-Limit': PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_IP.toString(),
    89            'X-RateLimit-Remaining': '0',
    90            'X-RateLimit-Reset': ipRateLimitResult.resetAt.toISOString(),
    91          },
    92        }
    93      )
    94    }
    95
    96    const body = await req.json()
    97    const { project_name, webhook_url, allowed_origins } = body
    98
    99    // Validation
   100    if (!project_name || project_name.length < 2 || project_name.length > 100) {
   101      return NextResponse.json(
   102        { error: 'Project name must be between 2 and 100 characters' },
   103        { status: 400 }
   104      )
   105    }
   106
   107    const pool = getPool()
   108    const slug = generateSlug(project_name)
   109
   110    // Create tenant
   111    const tenantResult = await pool.query(
   112      `INSERT INTO tenants (name, slug, settings)
   113       VALUES ($1, $2, $3)
   114       RETURNING id`,
   115      [project_name, slug, {}]
   116    )
   117
   118    const tenantId = tenantResult.rows[0].id
   119
   120    // Generate API keys
   121    const publicKey = generateApiKey('public')
   122    const secretKey = generateApiKey('secret')
   123
   124    // Create project
   125    const projectResult = await pool.query(
   126      `INSERT INTO projects (
   127         developer_id, project_name, tenant_id, webhook_url, allowed_origins, rate_limit
   128       )
   129       VALUES ($1, $2, $3, $4, $5, $6)
   130       RETURNING id, project_name, tenant_id, created_at`,
   131      [developer.id, project_name, tenantId, webhook_url, allowed_origins, 1000]
   132    )
   133
   134    const project = projectResult.rows[0]
   135
   136    // Create API keys
   137    await pool.query(
   138      `INSERT INTO api_keys (project_id, key_type, key_prefix, key_hash, scopes)
   139       VALUES ($1, 'public', $2, $3, $4)`,
   140      [project.id, 'nm_live_pk_', hashApiKey(publicKey), ['read']]
   141    )
   142
   143    await pool.query(
   144      `INSERT INTO api_keys (project_id, key_type, key_prefix, key_hash, scopes)
   145       VALUES ($1, 'secret', $2, $3, $4)`,
   146      [project.id, 'nm_live_sk_', hashApiKey(secretKey), ['read', 'write']]
   147    )
   148
   149    // Apply default quotas to the new project
   150    await applyDefaultQuotas(project.id)
   151
   152    // Log project creation
   153    await logProjectAction.created(
   154      userActor(developer.id),
   155      project.id,
   156      {
   157        metadata: {
   158          project_name: project.project_name,
   159          tenant_id: tenantId,
   160          webhook_url,
   161          allowed_origins,
   162        },
   163        request: {
   164          ip: clientIP || undefined,
   165          userAgent: req.headers.get('user-agent') || undefined,
   166        },
   167      }
   168    )
   169
   170    return NextResponse.json(
   171      {
   172        project: {
   173          id: project.id,
   174          name: project.project_name,
   175          slug: slug,
   176          tenant_id: project.tenant_id,
   177          created_at: project.created_at,
   178        },
   179        api_keys: {
   180          public_key: publicKey,
   181          secret_key: secretKey,
   182        },
   183        endpoints: {
   184          gateway: 'https://api.nextmavens.cloud',
   185          auth: 'https://auth.nextmavens.cloud',
   186          graphql: 'https://graphql.nextmavens.cloud',
   187          rest: 'https://api.nextmavens.cloud',
   188          realtime: 'wss://realtime.nextmavens.cloud',
   189          storage: 'https://telegram.nextmavens.cloud',
   190        },
   191        database_url: `postgresql://nextmavens:Elishiba@95@nextmavens-db-m4sxnf.1.mvuvh68efk7jnvynmv8r2jm2u:5432/nextmavens?options=--search_path=tenant_${slug}`,
   192        warning: "Save your API keys now! You won't be able to see the secret key again.",
   193      },
   194      {
   195        status: 201,
   196        headers: {
   197          'X-RateLimit-Limit': PROJECTS_PER_HOUR_PER_ORG.toString(),
   198          'X-RateLimit-Remaining': orgRateLimitResult.remainingAttempts.toString(),
   199          'X-RateLimit-Reset': orgRateLimitResult.resetAt.toISOString(),
   200        },
   201      }
   202    )
   203  } catch (error: any) {
   204    console.error('[Developer Portal] Create project error:', error)
   205    return NextResponse.json(
   206      { error: error.message || 'Failed to create project' },
   207      { status: error.message === 'No token provided' ? 401 : 500 }
   208    )
   209  }
   210}
   211
   212export async function GET(req: NextRequest) {
   213  try {
   214    const developer = await authenticateRequest(req)
   215    const pool = getPool()
   216
   217    const result = await pool.query(
   218      `SELECT
   219         p.id, p.project_name, p.tenant_id, p.webhook_url,
   220         p.allowed_origins, p.rate_limit, p.created_at,
   221         t.slug as tenant_slug,
   222         COUNT(DISTINCT ak.id) as api_keys_count
   223       FROM projects p
   224       JOIN tenants t ON p.tenant_id = t.id
   225       LEFT JOIN api_keys ak ON p.id = ak.project_id
   226       WHERE p.developer_id = $1
   227       GROUP BY p.id, t.slug
   228       ORDER BY p.created_at DESC`,
   229      [developer.id]
   230    )
   231
   232    const projects = result.rows.map(p => ({
   233      id: p.id,
   234      name: p.project_name,
   235      slug: p.tenant_slug,
   236      created_at: p.created_at,
   237    }))
   238
   239    return NextResponse.json({ projects })
   240  } catch (error: any) {
   241    console.error('[Developer Portal] List projects error:', error)
   242    return NextResponse.json(
   243      { error: error.message || 'Failed to list projects' },
   244      { status: error.message === 'No token provided' ? 401 : 500 }
   245    )
   246  }
   247}
   248

data.prompt:
Thoroughly audit the Developer Portal at /home/ken/developer-portal to determine if it's ready for developers to start integrating apps.

Check:
1. What features are available for developers (API keys, app creation, documentation, etc.)
2. Authentication and registration flow
3. API endpoints available for integration
4. UI/UX completeness (any TODO or placeholder pages)
5. Database schemas for developers/apps
6. Any missing critical features
7. Configuration completeness

Also audit the MCP (Model Context Protocol) setup:
1. Look for MCP server configurations in nextmavens-mcp-server directory
2. Check if MCPs are properly integrated with the platform
3. Verify MCP connectivity and configuration
4. Look for any MCP-related issues

Provide a detailed report on:
- Developer Portal readiness status
- What works, what's missing, what needs fixing
- MCP setup status and any issues
